facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 430 of 1957 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURiSDICTION Civil Appeal No. 430 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and decree dated 27th October 1953 of Judicial Commissioner Ajmer in Civil Second Appeal No. 25 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated 27th October, 1953, of the former Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, in Civil Second Appeal No. 25 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment confirms District Judge Ajmer and sets aside Subordinate Judge First Class Ajmer in Civil Suit No. 48 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer dated October 27, 1953, companyfirming the judgment of the District Judge, Ajmer, and setting aside that of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Ajmer, in Civil Suit No. 48 of 1944.

facts.text: Plaintiff Lakshman Singh is grandson of Sobhag Singh, paternal nephew of defendant Moti Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The following genealogy will be useful to appreciate the companytentions, of the parties Aman Singh Sujan Singh Sobhag Singh Moti Singh Zalim Singh  defendant  Lakshamn Singh  plaintiff

facts.text: In 1923, Sujan Singh aged about 70 years, Moti Singh about 50 years, Rup Kanwar about 45 years old.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1923, Sujan Singh was aged about 70 years, and Moti Singh was about 50 years, and Moti Singhs wife, Rup Kanwar alias Rup Kanwar Bai, the respondent herein,

facts.text: Moti Singh had no son, Sujan Singh anxious to have boy adopted to Moti Singh.

anchor.surface_text: who was subsequently brought on s record in place of Moti Singh after his death, was about 45 years old. Moti Singh had numberson and, therefore, Sujan Singh was anxious

facts.text: On February 14, 1923, plaintiff brought from father's house to Sujan Singh's house in Ajmer by Hira Lal.

anchor.surface_text: On February 14, 1923, the plaintiff was brought from his fathers house to the house of Sujan Singh in Ajmer by one Hira Lal and left there.

facts.text: On March 28, 1923, plaintiff admitted as student in Gurukul Kangri.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1923, the plaintiff was admitted as a student in an institution called Gurukul Kangri.

facts.text: Plaintiff educated in Gurukul from 1923 to 1936.

anchor.surface_text: He was educated in that institute from the year 1923 to 1936.

facts.text: On March 19, 1936, plaintiff returned to Moti Singh's house after completing studies.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1936, after companypleting his studies in the Gurukul, the plaintiff came back to Moti Singhs house.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed Civil Suit No. 48 of 1944 against Moti Singh for declaration as adopted son.

anchor.surface_text: As he was number accorded the treatment expected of an adoptive father to an adopted son, he grew apprehensive of the intentions of Moti Singh and filed Civil Suit No. 48 of 1944 against Moti Singh

facts.text: Moti Singh in written statement denied adoption and pleaded suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Moti Singh in his written statement denied that the plaintiff was his adopted son and pleaded that the suit was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held plaintiff adopted and suit not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, on evidence, held that the plaintiff was the adopted son of the defendant and that the suit was number barred by limitation.

facts.text: District Judge held plaintiff not adopted, no ceremony of giving and taking, suit within time.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the District Judge, on a review of the evidence, came to the companyclusion that the plaintiff was never in fact adopted by the defendant and that the ceremony of giving and taking did number take place.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner accepted District Judge findings and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On second appeal, the learned Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, accepted the findings of the learned District Judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Plaint alleged on 2nd June 1926 Kothari Sujan Singhji executed document announcing plaintiff as heir by adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The only allegation found in the plaint, was that on the 2nd June, 1926, Kothari Sujan Singhji executed a document announcing the plaintiff by virtue of his adoption by the defendant

facts.text: On October 24, 1942, trial court directed plaintiff to give particulars of adoption date and amend plaint.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1942, the trial companyrt directed the plaintiff to give further particulars about the date of the alleged adoption and to amend his plaint.

facts.text: On November 3, 1942, plaintiff alleged adoption between February 13, 1923 and February 23, 1923.

anchor.surface_text: On November 3, 1942, he filed a statement of further particulars alleging that he was taken in adoption between February 13, 1923, and February 23, 1923.

facts.text: Ex. P/1 dated October 21, 1922, letter by Sujan Singh to Zalim Singh about sending Lakshman Singh to Gurukul.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. P/1 dated October 21, 1922, is the letter written by Sujan Singh, the father of the defendant, to Zalim Singh, the father of the plaintiff. Therein it was stated that Lakshman Singh would be sent to Gurukul

facts.text: Ex. P/2 postcard dated January 31, 1923, by Moti Singh to Zalim Singh asking to send boy for Gurukul admission on Feb 20, no coconut ceremony before.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. P/2 is a post-card dated January 31, 1923, written by Moti Singh to Zalim Singh. Therein Moti Singh asked Zalim Singh to send Lakshman Singh, as he had to be admitted in Gurukul on February 20, 1923.

facts.text: Lakshman Singh letter to father Zalim Singh on May 19, 1934, stating no actual adoption yet.

anchor.surface_text: What is more, whatever doubts there may have been, they are clearly dispelled by a letter written by Laksman Singh to his father, Zalim Singh, on May 19, 1934, i.e., after disputes arose between the parties.

facts.text: Court held no ceremony of giving and taking took place.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, on the evidence, oral and documentary, that Sujan Singh and Moti Singh wanted to take the plaintiff in adoption either after the boy was admitted in Gurukul or after he finished his education therein,

facts.text: Hira Lal brought plaintiff to Ajmer on instructions to leave him for Gurukul, not for adoption ceremony.

anchor.surface_text: Hira Lal, as D.W. 4, described the incident thus In 1923 1 brought Lachman Singh to Ajmer. I brought him to the house of Sujan Singh and Moti Singh. I was informed by Zalim Singh that Moti Singh had written

facts.text: Supreme Court holds plaintiff not adopted by Moti Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold, agreeing with the Judicial Commissioner, that the appellant was number adopted by Moti Singh.

facts.text: Moti Singh died, Rup Kanwar brought on record as respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contended that the Judicial Commissioner has not correctly appreciated the ingredients of the ceremony of giving and taking and that he should have held that Hira Lals bringing of the boy at the instance of his natural father to the house of Sujan Singh, and Moti Singh receiving the boy by putting his hand on his head were sufficient compliance with the Hindu Law doctrine of giving and taking and, therefore, the adoption was valid.

arguments.claim: Zalim Singh sending plaintiff through Hira Lal and Moti Singh receiving him sufficient compliance with giving and taking pursuant to settled intention; natural father can delegate physical handing over to third party

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was contended that the fact that Zalim Singh sent the plaintiff through Hira Lal to Moti Singhs house and that Moti Singh received him in his house would be sufficient compliance in law with the requirement of giving and taking as understood in the Hindu Law, when those events took pursuant to the settled intention of the parties to take the plaintiff in adoption. A natural father, the argument proceeded, need not physically hand over the boy to the adoptive father, but he could validly delegate the physical act of handing over the boy to a third party as Zalim Singh is alleged to have done in the present case.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold, on the evidence, oral and documentary, that Sujan Singh and Moti Singh wanted to take the plaintiff in adoption either after the boy was admitted in Gurukul or after he finished his education therein, that Hira Lal, on the request of the plaintiffs father, accompanied the boy to Sujan Singhs house at Ajmer and left him there, that Moti Singh welcomed the boy as was expected of him and thereafter sent him to Gurukul and that no formal ceremony of giving and taking had taken place.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, on the evidence, oral and documentary, that Sujan Singh and Moti Singh wanted to take the plaintiff in adoption either after the boy was admitted in Gurukul or after he finished his education therein, that Hira Lal, on the request of the plaintiffs father, accompanied the boy to Sujan Singhs house at Ajmer and left him there, that Moti Singh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral evidence of Hira Lal and others, documentary evidence including letters Ex.P/1, P/2, P/3, plaintiff's letter of 1934, and will Ex.P/26 show boy brought for Gurukul admission, adoption intended later.

holdings.text: the fact that Zalim Singh sent the plaintiff through Hira Lal to Moti Singhs house and that Moti Singh received him in his house would be [not] sufficient compliance in law with the requirement of giving and taking as understood in the Hindu Law

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it was contended that the fact that Zalim Singh sent the plaintiff through Hira Lal to Moti Singhs house and that Moti Singh received him in his house would be sufficient compliance in law with the requirement of giving and taking as understood in the Hindu Law, when those events took pursuant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Events occurred pursuant to sending for Gurukul, not settled intention for immediate adoption; no proof of delegation for adoption ceremony.

holdings.text: We therefore, hold that the ceremony of giving and taking, which is very essential for the validity of an adoption, had not taken place in this case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior exercise of volition to adopt on Feb 14; no unavoidable circumstances requiring delegation; Hira Lal not instructed to perform adoption giving; Moti Singh received boy to send to Gurukul.

holdings.text: Under the Hindu Law, whether among the regenerate caste or among Sudras, there cannot be a valid adoption unless the adoptive boy is transferred from one family to another and that can be done only by the ceremony of giving and taking.

anchor.surface_text: The law may be briefly stated thus Under the Hindu Law, whether among the regenerate caste or among Sudras, there cannot be a valid adoption unless the adoptive boy is transferred from one family to another and that can be done only by the ceremony of giving and taking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ceremony ensures publicity; actual physical transfer required; texts of Sarkar Sastri and Mayne, precedents like Shoshinath Ghose and Krishna Rao affirm essentiality even for Sudras.

holdings.text: after the natural and adoptive parents exercised their volition to give and take the boy in adoption, either of them could, under certain unavoidable compelling circumstances, delegate his right to give or the right to receive the adoptive son, as the case may be, to a third party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts recognize delegation for physical act only post-volition and due to infirmity etc.; precedents Vijiarangam, Shamsing, Viyyamma approve vicarious performance for publicity.

holdings.text: the Judicial Committee, in our view, did not intend to depart from the well recognized doctrine of Hindu Law that there should be a ceremony of giving and taking to validate an adoption.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Biradhmal held registration occasion for simple ceremony with boy present; not that Sub-Registrar questions alone suffice as giving/taking.

holdings.text: In the present case, none of the aforesaid conditions has been satisfied.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings on no decision on Feb 14, intention post-Gurukul; no delegation; reception for education not ceremony.

holdings.text: In the result, we hold, agreeing with the Judicial Commissioner, that the appellant was not adopted by Moti Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold, agreeing with the Judicial Commissioner, that the appellant was not adopted by Moti Singh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming lower courts on evidence and law of giving/taking and delegation.

anchor.surface_text: Shoshinath Ghose v. Krishnasundari Dasi 1 . That was, like the present, a case of adoption among Sudras. There, it was contended, inter alia, that there was a formal adoption by giving and taking, and in the alternative it was contended that even if there had been no formal adoption as alleged, the deeds of giving and taking, executed in 1864, were sufficient to bring about the adoption and that was all that was essential in the case of Sudras. Sir J. W. Colvile, speaking for the Board, rejected both the contentions.

precedents.cited_proposition: Formal ceremony of giving and taking is essential for valid adoption even among Sudras; deeds alone do not constitute giving and taking
precedents.cited_holding: There is no decided case which shows that there can be an adoption by deed... amongst Sudras, no ceremonies are necessary in addition to the giving and taking of the child in adoption

precedents.citation: Krishna Rao v. Sundara Siva Rao 1

anchor.surface_text: Krishna Rao v. Sundara Siva Rao 1 . But in practice many situations had arisen when it became impossible for a natural father to hand over the adoptive boy physically, or to an adoptive father or mother to receive the adoptive boy physically due to physical infirmity or other causes. In such cases Courts have stepped in and recognized the delegation of the physical act of giving and taking provided there was an agreement between the natural and adoptive parents to give and receive the boy in adoption.

precedents.case_name: Krishna Rao v Sundara Siva Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: Formal ceremony of giving and taking is essential to validate the adoption

anchor.surface_text: Vijiarangam v. Lakshuman 2 thus The gift and acceptance in such a case must, as Sir T. Strange has observed be manifested by some overt act and here Yeshvadabai did not in person hand over her son to Savitri. But she commissioned her uncle to do this, being at the time too unwell to attend the ceremony herself. The Hindu Law recognizes the vicarious performance of most legal acts the object of the corporeal giving and receiv- ing in adoption is obviously to secure due publicity

precedents.cited_proposition: Natural parent can delegate the physical act of giving the boy in adoption to a third party under unavoidable circumstances like illness
precedents.cited_holding: the adoption is proved and effectual

anchor.surface_text: Shamsing v. Santabai 1 . A division bench of the Madras High Court in Viyyamma v. Suryaprakasa Rao 2 applied the principle to a converse case of an adoptive father delegating his power to accept the adoptive boy to another. Sir Lionel Leach, C.J., in extending the rule of delegation to a case of receiving says at p. 613 thus If this were not so, what would be the position when through accident or illness the natural father or the adoptive parent could not be present in person to do what is necessary?

precedents.cited_proposition: Approved the view allowing delegation of physical act of giving

anchor.surface_text: Viyyamma v. Suryaprakasa Rao 2 applied the principle to a converse case of an adoptive father delegating his power to accept the adoptive boy to another. Sir Lionel Leach, C.J., in extending the rule of delegation to a case of receiving says at p. 613 thus If this were not so, what would be the position when through accident or illness the natural father or the adoptive parent could not be present in person to do what is necessary? There could be no adoption. Further citation would be redundant.

precedents.cited_proposition: Adoptive parent can delegate the physical act of receiving the boy

anchor.surface_text: Biradhmal v. Prabhabhati 3 . There a widow executed a deed of adoption whereby she purported to have adopted as son to her deceased husband a boy. The Sub-Registrar before whom the document was registered put to the boys natural father and to the widow questions whether they had executed the deed. The boy was also present at that time. The Judicial Committee held that, under the said circumstances, there was proof of giving and taking.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presence of boy at registration where sub-registrar questions natural father and adoptive mother suffices as giving and taking
precedents.cited_holding: the evidence that the boy was present at the time when the sub-registrar put to his father and to the widow the questions whether they had executed the deed is sufficient to prove a giving and taking
